bibl.note: Transcribed by the Text Creation Partnership and corrected by the staff of the Spenser Project. All variants transcribed by the staff of the Spenser Project from collations of the following copies:

normalization.p: Spacing between words and punctuation has been regularized to zero spaces; spacing between words has been regularized to one space.
Long s, i/j, u/v, and VV (for W) have been changed to correspond to modern typographical convention.
Obvious compositorial errors (e.g. foul case ) have been corrected.

docTitle.titlePart:
Written by that Renowned Poët,
Edmond Spenser.

titlePage.docImprint:
London
Printed for Thomas Walkley, and
are to be sold at his shop at the Eagle and
Child in Brittaines Bursse.1628

div.head:
TO THE RIGHT
Noble Lady MARY,
Daughter to the most Illustri-
ous Prince George, Duke
of Buckingham.
div.p:
MOST NOBLE LADY: I havehaue presumed to present this little Poem to your Honourable hand, encouraged onely by the worth of the Famous Author (for I am certainely assured by the ablest, and most knowing men, that it must be a Worke of Spencers, of whom it were pitty that any thing
should bee lost ) and doubting not but your Lady-ship will graciously accept, though from a meane hand, this humble present,

lg.l: since the man that offers it, is
a true Honourer and Obseruer of
your Selfe, and your Princely
Family, and shall euer
remaine
The humblest of your
devoteddeuoted ServantsSeruants.

l.hi: Thomas Walkley
Accipe facundi culicem studiose Maronis,
Ne nugis positis, arma virumque Canas
S
E here that stately Muse, that erst could raise,
In lasting numbers great Elizaes praise,
And drese faire Vertue in so rich attire
That euen her Foes were forced to admire,
And court her Heauenly beauty, shee that taught
The Graces grace, and made the Vertues thought
More vertuous then before, is pleased here
To slacke her serious flight, and feed your eare
With loues delightsome toyes; doe not refuse
These harmlesse sports, ’tis learned Spencer’s Muse;
But thinke his loosest Poëms worthier then
The serious follies of vnskillfull men.
The youthly Shepheards wonning here,
And Beauties rare displayd appeare.appeare:
What exercise hee chiefe affects,
His Name, and scornefull loue neglects.

lg.head: I
lg.l: IN Ida Vale (who knowes not Ida Vale?)
When harmelesse Troy yet felt not Graecian spite:
A hundred Shepheards woon’d, and in the Dale,
While their faire Flockes the three leau’d Pastures bite:
The Shepheards boyes, with hundred sportings light,
GaveGaue winges untovnto the times to speedy hast:
Ah foolish Lads, that strovestroue with lavishlauish wast,
So fast to spend the time, that spends your time as fast.
Among the rest that all the rest excel’d,
A dainty Boy there wonn’d, whose harmelesse yeares,
Now in their freshest budding gently sweld;
His Nimph-like face ne’re felt the nimble sheeres,
Youth’s downy blossome through his cheeke appeares:
His lovelylouely limbes (but loveloue he quite discarded)
Were made for play (but he no play regarded,)
And fit loveloue to reward; and with loue be rewarded.
High was his fore-head, arch’t with sliversiluer mould,
(Where neverneuer anger churlish rinkle dighted
His auburne lockes hung like darke threds of gold,
That wanton aires (with their faire length incited)
To play among theit wanton curles delighted.
His smiling eyes with simple truth were stor’d:
Ah! how should truth in those thiefe eyes be stor’d,
Which thousand lovesloues had stol’n, and neverneuer one restor’d.
His lilly-cheeke might seeme an IvoryIuory plaine,
More purely white than frozen Apenine:
Where lovelylouely bashfulnesse did sweetely raine,
In blushing scarlet cloth’d, and purple fine.
A hundred hearts had this delightfull shrine,
(Still cold it selfe) inflam’d with hot desire,
That well the face might seeme, in diversdiuers tire,
To be a burning snow, or else a freezing fire
His cheerefull lookes, and merry face would prooveprooue
(If eyes the index be where thoughts are read)
A dainty play-fellow for naked loveloue;
Of all the other parts enough is sed,
That they were fit twins for so fayre a head:
Thousand boyes for him, thousand maidens dy’de,
Dye they that list, for such his rigorous pride,
Ne thousand boyes (ah foole) and thousand maids deni’d.
His joyioy was not in musiques sweete delight,
(Though well his hand had learnt that cunning arte)
Or dainty songs to daintier eares indite;
But through the plaines to chace the nimble Hart,
With well-run’d hounds; or with his certaine dart,
The tusked Boare, or savagesauage Beare to wound;
Meane time his heart with monsters doth abound,
Ah foole to seeke so farre what neerer might be found!found !
His name (well knowne vnto those Woody shades,
Where unrewardedvnrewarded loverslouers oft complaine them)
Anchises was:was; Anchises oft the glades.glades,
And mountaines heard Anchises had disdain’d them;
Not all their loue one gentle looke had gain’d them,
That rockey hills, with echoing noyse consenting,
Anchises plain’d,plain’d; but he no whit relenting,
(Harder then rocky hils) laught at their vaine lamenting.

l.hi: Diones
Garden of delight,
With wonder holds
sight;
While from the Bower such Musique sounds,
As all his senses neere confounds.

lg.l: ONe day it chanc’t as hee the Deere persude,
Tyred with sport, and faint with weary play,
Faire Venus grovegroue not farre away he view’d,
Whose trembling leavesleaues inviteinuite him there to stay,
And in their shades his sweating limbes display:
There in the cooling glade he softly paces,
And much delighted with their eveneuen spaces,
What in himselfe he scorn’d, hee prais’d their kinde imbraces:
The Woode with Paphian myrtlespahphianmirtles peopled,
(Whose springing youth felt neverneuer Winters spiting)
To laurels sweete were sweetely married,
Doubling their pleasing smels in their unitingvniting,
When single much, much more when mixt delighting:
No foote of beast durst touch this hallowed place,
And many a boy that long’d the woods to trace,
Entred with feare, but soone turn’d back his frighted face.
The thicke-lockt bowes shut out the tell-tale Sunne,
(For Venus hated his all blabbing light,
Since her knowne fault which oft she wisht undonevndone)
And scattered rayes did make a doubtfull fight,
Like to the first of day, or last of night:
The fittest light for LoversLouers gentle play;
Such light best shewes the wandring loverslouers way,
And guides his erring hand: Night is lovesloues holly-day.
So farre in this sweete Labyrinth he stray’d,
That now he viewes the Garden of delight;
Whose breast, with thousand painted flowers array’d,
With diversdiuers joyioy captiv’dcaptiu’d his wandring sight;
But soone the eyes rendred the eares their right:
For such strange harmony he seem’d to heare,
That all his senses flockt into his eare,
And everyeuery faculty wisht to be seated there.
From a close Bower this dainty Musique flow’d,
A Bower appareld round with diversdiuers Roses
Both red and white; which by their liveriesliueries show’d
Their Mistris faire, that there her selfe reposes:
Seem’d that would strivestriue with those rare Musique clozes,
By spreading their faire bosomes to the light,
Which the distracted sense should most delight
That, raps the melted eare; this, boththis,both the smel and& sight
The Boy ’twixt fearefull hope, and wishing feare,
Crept all a long (for much he long’d to see
The Bower, much more the guest so lodged there)
And as he goes, he markes how well agree
Nature and arte in discord unityvnity:
Each strivingstriuing who should best performe his part,
Yet arte now helping nature; nature arte:
While from his eares a voyce thus stole his heart.
Fond men, whose wretched care the life soone ending,
By strivingstriuing to increaseiucrease your joyioy, do spend it;
And spending joyioy, yet find no joyioy in spending:
You hurt your life by strivingstriuing to amend it,
And seeking to prolong it, soonest end it:
Than while fit time affords thee time and leasure,
Enioy while yet thou mayst thy lifes sweet pleasure:
Too foolish is the man that starvesstarues to feed his treasure:
LoveLoue is lifes end (an end but neverneuer ending)
All joyesioyes, all sweetes, all happinesse awarding:
LoveLoue is life wealth (nere spent, but evereuer spending)
More rich, by givinggiuing, taking by discarding:
Love’sLoue’s lifes reward, rewarded in rewarding,
Then from thy wretched heart fond care remooveremooue;
Ah should thou liveliue but once lovesloues sweetes to prooveprooue,
Thou wilt not loveloue to liveliue, unlessevnlesse thou liveliue to loveloue.
To this sweete voyce, a dainty musique fitted
It’s well-tun’d strings; and to her notes consorted:
And while with skilfull voyce the song she dittied,
The blabbing Echo had her words retorted;
That now the Boy, beyond his soule transported,
Through all his limbes feeles run a pleasant shaking,
And twixt a hope and& feare suspects mistaking,
And doubts he sleeping dreames, and& broad awake feares waking.

l.hi: Faire
Cythareas
limbes beheld,
The straying Lads heart so inthral’d:
That in a Trance his melted spright,
Leaues th’ sencesth’sences slumbring in delight.

lg.l: NOw to the Bower hee sent his theevishtheeuish eyes,
To steale a happy sight; there doe they finde
Faire Venus, that within halfe naked lyes;
And straight amaz’d (so glorious beauty shin’d)
Would not returne the message to the minde:
But full of feare, and superstitious awe,
Could not retire, or backe their beames with-draw,
So fixt on, too much seeing made they nothing saw.
Her goodly length, stretch’t on a Lilly-bed;
(A bright foyle of a beauty farre more bright,)
Few Roses round about were scattered,
As if the Lillies learnt to blush for spite,
To see a skinne much more then Lilly-white:
The bed sanke with delight so to be pressed,
And knew not which to thinke a chance more blessed,
Both blessed so to kisse, and so agayne be kissed.
Her spacious fore-head like the clearest Moone,
Whose full-growne Orbe begins now to be spent,
Largely display’d in nativenatiue silversiluer shone,
GivingGiuing wide roome to beauties Regiment,
Which on the plaine with loveloue tryumphing went:
Her golden haire a rope of pearle imbraced,
Which with their dainty threds oft times enlaced,
Made the eie think the pearle was there in gold inchased.
Her full large eye, in jetty-blackeietty-blacke array’d,
Prov’dProu’d beauty not confin’d to red and white,
But oft her selfe in blacke more rich display’d;
Both contraries did yet themselues unitevnite,
To make one beauty in different delight:
A thousand lovesloues sate playing in each eye,
And smiling mirth kissing faire courtesie,
By sweete perswasion wan a bloodlesse victory.
The whitest white set by her silversiluer cheeke,
Grew pale and wan like untovnto heavyheauy lead:
The freshest Purple fresher dyes must seeke,
That dares compare with them his fainting red:
On these Cupio winged armies led,
Of little lovesloues, that with bold wanton traine
UnderVnder those colours, marching on the plaine,
Force euery heart, andheart,and to low vasselage constraine.
Her lips, most happy each in others kisses,
From their so wisht imbracements seldome parted,
Yet seem’d to blush at such their wanton blisses;
But when sweete words their joyningioyning sweet disparted,
To th’eare a dainty musique they imparted:
UponVpon them fitly sate delightfull smiling,
A thousand soules with pleasing stealth beguiling:
Ah that such shew’s of joyesioyes should be all joyesioyes exiling?
The breath came slowly thence, vnwillingunwilling leavingleauing
So sweet a lodge, but when she once intended,
To feast the aire with words, the heart deceivingdecieuing,
More fast it thronged so to be expended;
And at each word a hundred lovesloues attended,
Playing i’th breathith’breath, more sweete then is that firing,
Where that Arabian onely bird expiring,
LivesLiues by her death, by losse of breath more fresh respiring.
Her chin, like to a stone in gold inchased,
Seem’d a faire jewelliewell wrought with cunning hand,
And being double, doubly the face graced.
This goodly frame on her round necke did stand,
Such pillar, well such curious worke sustain’d;
And on his top the heavenlyheauenly spheare upvp rearing,
Might well present, with daintier appearing,
A lesse but better Atlas, that faire heavenheauen bearing.
Lower two breasts stand all their beauties bearing,
Two breasts as smooth and soft--soft; but ah alas!alas !
Their smoothest softnes farre exceedes comparing:
More smooth and soft--soft; but naught that evereuer was,
Where they are first deservesdeserues the second place:
Yet each as soft and each as smooth as other;
And whe~when thou first tri’st one and& the~then the other,
Each softer seemes then each, and& each then each seemes smoother.
Lowly betweene their dainty hemisphaeres,
(Their hemisphaeres the heav’nlyheau’nly Globes excelling,)
A path, more white then is the name it beares,
The lacteall path, conducts to the sweet dwelling,
Where best delight all joyesioyes sits freely dealing;
Where hundred sweetes, and still fresh joyesioyes attending;
Receiue in givingingiuing, and still loue dispending,
Grow richer by their losse, andlosse,and wealthy by expending.
But stay bold shepheard, here thy footing stay,
Nor trust too much vnto thy new-bornenow-borne quill,
As farther to those dainty limbes to stray;
Or hope to paint that vale, or beautious hill,
Which past the finest hand and choycest skill:
But were thy Verse and Song as finely fram’d,
As are those parts, yet should it soone be blam’d,
For now the shameles world of best things is asham’d.
That cunning Artist, that old Greece admir’d,
Thus farre his Venus fitly portrayed;
But there he left, nor farther ere aspir’d:
His Daedale hand, that Nature perfected
By arte, felt arte by nature limitted.
Ah! well he knew, though his fit hand could givegiue
Breath to dead colours, teaching marble liveliue,
Yet would these livelyliuely parts his hand of skill deprivedepriue.
Such when this gentle boy her closly view’d,
Onely with thinnest silken vaile o’er-layd,
Whose snowy colour much more snowy shew’d,
By being next that skin; and all betray’d,
Which best in naked beauties are aray’d:
His spirits melted with so glorious sight,
Ran from their worke to see so splendent light,
And left the fainting limbes sweet slumbring in delight.

l.hi: The swonding Swaine recouered is
By th’Goddesse; his soule rapting blisse:
There mutuàll conference, andconference,and how
Her serviceseruice she doth him allow.

lg.l: SOft-sleeping Venus waked with the fall,
Looking behind, the sinking Boy espies,
With all she starts, and wondereth withall,
She thinkes that there her faire Adonis dyes,
And more she thinkes the more the Boy she eyes:
So stepping neerer, upvp begins to reare him;
And now with loveloue himselfe she will confer him,
And now, before her loveloue himselfe she will preferre him:
The Lad soone with that dainty touch reviv’dreuiu’d,
Feeling himselfe so well, so sweetly seated,
Begins to doubt whether he yet here liv’dliu’d,
Or else his flitting soule to heav’nheau’n translated,
Was there in starry throne, and blisse instated:
Oft would he dye, so to be often savedsaued;
And now with happy wish he closly cravedcraued,
For evereuer to be dead, to be so sweet ingravedingraued.
The paphian Princesse (in whose louely breast,
Spitefull disdaine could neverneuer find a place)
When now she saw him from his fit releast,
(To JunoIuno leauing wrath, and scolding base)
Comforts the trembling Boy with smiling grace,
But oh!oh ! those smiles (too full of sweete delight)
Surfeit his heart, full of the former sight;
So seeking to revivereuiue, more wounds his feeble sprite.
Tell me faire Boy (sayd she) what erring chance,
Hither directed thy unwaryvnwary pace:
For sure contempt, or pride durst not advanceaduance
Their foule aspect, in thy so pleasant face:
Tell me, what brought thee to this hidden place?
Or lacke of loveloue, or mutuall answering fire,
Or hindred by ill chance in thy desire:
Tell me, what ist thy faire and wishing eyes require?
The Boy (whose sence was neverneuer yet acquainted
WithWith) such a musique) stood with eares arected;
And sweetly with that pleasant spell enchanted,
More of those sugred straines long time expected,
Till seeing she his speeches not rejectedreiected,
First sighes arising from his hearts low center,
Thus gan reply; when each word bold would venter,
And strivestriue the first, that dainty labyrinth to enter,
“FaireFaire cyprian Queene (for well that heauenly face)
ProovesProoues thee the mother of all conquering loveloue)
Pardon I pray thee my unweetingvnweeting pace,
For no presumptuous thoughts did hither moovemooue
My daring feete, to this thy holy GroveGroue;
But lucklesse chance (which if you not gaine say,
I still must rue) hath caus’d me here to stray,
And lose my selfe (alas) in losing of my way.
Nor did I come to right my wronged fire,
NeverNeuer till now I saw what ought be lovedloued,
And now I see, but neverneuer dare aspire
To moovemooue my hope, where yet my loveloue is moovedmooued;
Whence though I would, I would it not remoovedremooued:
Onely since I haue plac’t my loveloue so high,
Which sure thou must, or sure thou wilt deny,
Grant me yet still to loveloue, though in my loveloue to dye."dye..
But shee that in his eyes Love’sLoues face had seene,
And flaming heart, did not such suite disdaine,
(For cruelty fits not sweete beauties Queene)
But gently could his passion entertaine,
Though she love’sloues Princesse, he a lowly Swaine:
First of his bold intrusion she acquites him;
Then to her serviceseruice (happy Boy) admits him;
And like another loveloue, with Bow and quiverquiuer fits him.
And now with allwithall the loues he grew acquainted,
And Cupids selfe, with his like face delighted,
Taught him a hundred wayes with which he daunted
The prouder hearts, and wronged loverslouers righted,
Forcing to loveloue, that most his loveloue despited.
And now the practique Boy did so approoveapprooue him,
And with such grace and cunning arte did moovemooue him,
That all the pritty lovesloues, and all the Graces loveloue him.

l.hi: The Louers sadde despairingsaddedespairing plaints,
Bright Venus with his loveloue acquaints;
Sweetly importun’d hebe doth shew,
From whom proceedeth this his woe.

lg.l: YEt neuer durst his faint and coward heart,
(Ah foole! faint heart faire Lady ne’re could win)
Assaile faire Venus with his new-learnt arte,
But kept hishi loue, and burning flame within,
Which more flam’d out, the more he prest it in:
And thinkingthinkidg oft, how justiust shee might disdaine him;
While some coole mirtle shade did entertaine him,
Thus sighing would he sitfit, and& sadly would he plain him.
Ah fond, and haplesse Boy!Boy ! nor know I whether,
More fond, or haplesse more, that all so high
Hast plac’t thy heart, where loveloue and fate together,
May neverneuer hope to end thy misery,
Nor yet thy selfe dare wish a remedy.
All hindrances (alas) conspire to let it;
Ah fond, and haplesse Boy!Boy ! if canst not get it,
In thinking to forget, at length learne to forget it.
Ah farre too fond, but much more haplesse Swaine!Swaine !
Seeing thy loveloue can be forgotten neverneuer.
Serue and observeobserue thy loveloue with willing paine;
And though in vaine thy loue thou doe perseverperseuer,
Yet all in vaine doe thou adore her evereuer.
No hope can crowne thy thoughts so farre aspiring,
Nor dares thy selfe desire thine owne desiring,
Yet liveliue thou in her loveloue, and dye in her admiring.
Thus oft the hopelesse Boy complayning lyes;
But she that well could guesse his sad lamenting,
(Who can conceale loveloue from love’s mother’sloues mothers eyes?)
Did not disdaine to givegiue his loveloue contenting:
Cruell the soule, that feedesthatfeedes on soules tormenting:
Nor did she scorne him though not nobly borne,
(LoveLoue is nobility) nor could she scorne,
That with so noble skill her title did adorne.
One day it chanc’t, thrice happy day and chance!chance !
While lovesloues were with the Graces sweetly sporting,
And to fresh musique sounding play and dance;
And Cupids selfe, withselfe with Shepheards boyes consorting,
Laught at their pritty sport, and simple courting:
Faire Venus seates the fearefull Boy close by her,
Where neverneuer Phoebus JealousIealous lookes might eye her,
And bids the Boy his Mistris, and her name descry her.
Long time the youth bound upvp in silence stood,
While hope and feare with hundred thoughts begun,
Fit Prologue to his speech; and fearefull blood
From heart and face, with these post-tydings runne,
That eyther now he’s made, or now undonevndone:
At length his trembling words, with feare made weake,
Began his too long silence thus to breake,
While from his humble eies first reverencereuerence seem’d to speake,
“FaireFaire Queene of Loue, my life thou maist command,
Too slender price for all thy former grace,
Which I receiverecieue at thy so bounteous hand;
But neverneuer dare I speake her name and face;
My life is much lesse-priz’d than her disgrace:
And, for I know if I her name relate,
I purchase anger, I must hide her state,
UnlesseVnlesse thou sweare by stix I purchase not her hate."hate.
Faire Venus well preciev’dprecieu’d his subtile shift,
And swearing gentle patience, gently smil’d:
While thus the Boy persu’d his former drift:
No tongue was evereuer yet so sweetely skil’d,
Nor greatest Orator so highly stil’d;
Though helpt withall the choisest artes direction,
But when he durst describe her heav’nsheau’ns perfection,
By his imperfect praise, disprais’d his imperfection.
Her forme is as her selfe, perfect Caelestriall,
No mortall spot her heauenly frame disgraces:
Beyond compare; such nothing is terrestriall;
More sweete then thought or pow’rfull wish embraces,
The map of heavenheauen; the summe of all the Graces.
But if you wish more livelytiuely limb’d to eye her,
Than fainting speech, or words can well descry her,
Look in a glasse, and& there more perfect you may spy her.

l.hi: The Boyes short wish, her larger grant,
That doth his soule with blisse enchant:
Whereof impatient utteringvttering all,
Inraged JoveIove contrivescontriues his thrall.

lg.l: “ThyThy crafty arte"arte (reply’d the smiling Queene)
“HathHath well my chiding, and not rage preventedpreuented,
Yet might’st thou thinke, that yet ’twas neverneuer seene,seene.
That angry rage, and gentle loveloue consented:
But if to me thy true loveloue is presented,
What wages for thy serviceseruice must I owe thee?
For by the selfe same vow, I here avowauow thee,
What evereuer thou require, I frankly will allow thee."thee.
“Pardon"Pardon (replies the Boy) “forfor so affecting,
Beyond mortallity; and not discarding,
Thy serviceseruice was much more than my expecting;
But if thou (more thy bounty-hood regarding)
Wilt needes heape upvp reward uponvpon rewarding;
Thy loveloue I dare not aske, or mutuall fixing,
One kisse is all my loveloue, and prides aspiring,
And after starvestarue my heart, for my too much desiring."desiring.
“Fond Boy!"Fond Boy! (sayd she) “tootoo fond that askt no more;
Thy want by taking is no whit decreased,
And givinggiuing, spends not our increasing store:"store:
Thus with a kisse, his lips she sweetly pressed;
Most blessed kisse; but hope more than most blessed,
The Boy did thinke heavenheauen fell while thus he joy’dioy’d;
And while joyioy he so greedily enoy’denoi’d,
He felt not halfe his joyioy by being over-joy’douer-ioy’d.
“WhyWhy sighst faire Boy?"Boy? (sayd she) “dostdost thou repent thee
Thy narrow wish in such straight bonds to stay?"stay?
“WellWell may I sigh"sigh (sayd he) “andand well lament me,
That neverneuer such a debt may hope to pay:"pay:
“AA kisse"kisse (sayd she) “aa kisse will backe repay:"repay:
“Wilt thou"Wilt thou (reply’d the Boy too much delighted)
“ContentContent thee, with such pay to be requited?"requited?
She grants; and;& he his lips, heart, soule, to payment cited.
Looke as a Ward, long from his Lands detain’d,
And subiect to his Guardians cruel lore,
Now spends the more, the more he was restrain’d,
So he; yet though in laying out his store,
He doubly takes; yet findes himselfe grow poore:
With that, he markes, and tels her out a score,
And doubles them, and trebles all before:
Fond Boy!Boy ! the more thou paist, thypaist,thy debt still grows the more.
At length, whether these favoursfauours so had fir’d him,
With kindly heate, inflaming his desiring;
Or whether those sweete kisses had inspir’d him;
Hee thinkes that some thing wants for his requiring;
And still aspires, yet knows not his aspiring:
But yet though that hee knoweth, soknoweth,so she gavegaue,
That he presents himselfe her bounden slaveslaue;
Stil his more wishing face seem’d some what else to cravecraue.
And boldned with successe and many graces,
His hand, chain’d upvp in feare, he now releast:
And asking leaveleaue, courag’d with her imbraces;
Againe it prison’d in her tender breast;
Ah blessed prison!prison ! prisners too much blest!blest !
There with those sisters long time doth he play;
And now full boldly enters love’sloues high way;
While downe the pleasant vale, his creeping hand doth stray.
She not displeased with this his wanton play,
Hiding his blushing with a sugred kisse;
With such sweete heat his rudenesse doth allay,
That now he perfect knowes what evereuer blisse,
Elder loveloue taught, and he before did misse:
That moult with joyioy, in such untri’dvntri’d joyesioyes trying,
He gladly dies; and death new lifeapplying,
Gladly againe he dyes, thatdyes,that oft he may be dying.
Long thus he liv’dliu’d, slumbring in sweete delight,
Free from sad care, and fickle worlds annoy;
Bathing in liquid joyesioyes his melted sprite;
And longer mought, but he (ah foolish Boy!Boy !)
Too proud, and to impatient of his joyioy,
To woods, and heav’nheau’n, and earth his blisse imparted;
That Jove Iove uponvpon him downe his thunder darted,
Blasting his splendent face, and all his beauty swarted.
Such be his chance, that to his loveloue doth wrong,
UnworthyVnworthy he to havehaue so worthy place,
That cannot hold his peace and blabbing tongue:
Light joyesioyes float on his lips, but rightly grace
Sinckes deepe, and th’hearts low center doth imbrace:
Might I enioy my loveloue till I unfoldvnfold it,
I’de lose all favoursfauours when I blabbing told it:
He is not fit for love, thatloue,that is not fit to hold it.
